title: How to write an attractive chemistry article - Quora

response.answer_text: Decide who you’re writing for. Are you writing it for children? Make sure you add plenty of pictures, preferably high quality and maybe aesthetically weirder ones. Think back to your childhood or browse a picture book the next time you’re in a store and you’ll learn what the word-to-picture ratio looks like. Also, don’t skimp on the art because kids can tell. Are you writing it for teens? Most high-school level wording works, I should think, because teens won’t be reading things unless they’re A) forced to or B) are already interested in the topic, hence their attention. Whichever the case, please don’t try to sound cool or hip. Just use language for adults with a depth level and sentence structure suitable for teens. Are you writing it for laymen? Write it to a depth level that you’d be able to pick up if it were a topic you didn’t understand. The important thing is in the packaging. Show how it affects common objects that they know to be regular, or part of their lives. If I saw an article titled* “The Effect of Phylliomeres on the Production of 5-Benzone and Other Gamete-Related Pheromones in Salienta Anura” you lost me. If, however, your title was “The FBI is Adding Chemicals to the Water to Make the Frogs Gay!” … you get the point. If you’re writing it for those in research, the more specific the better. Either your article pertains to the narrow pool of work and substances they’re using, in which case you are potentially a resource to quote and expand on… or your article doesn’t pertain to the narrow pool of work and substances they’re using, in which case you’re not a priority anyways. *The topic of example for me, evidently, being biology.
